sources.full: The Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things

deck.name: Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things (Overworld)
entries: The 5e {@item deck of many things} is a fantastic item with powerful magic. It can change your game in an instant, for better or worse. Each card drawn from the deck immediately impacts the character who draws from it, and in some cases, it can reshape reality itself.

You can use either the Overworld or Underworld half of the deck to represent this item in your games as a fun interactive tool for players. They can draw from the deck when they declare that their character will, or the Game Master (GM) can draw for them if you are playing online. The Overworld effects of the cards detailed in this booklet are the standard effects of the deck of many things.

However, the Fablemaker's deck of many things offers another way to play, bringing more risk and potentially more rewards than ever. The Underworld effects are an alternate version of the deck of many things. There are several ways to include these new effects in your game. You can choose to use only the Underworld effects of the cards, or you can flip a coin to determine whether the effect of a drawn card is the standard Overworld effect or the new Underworld effect. You can also shuffle both halves together and let the luck of the draw determine the effect by applying the effect matching the card drawn. For even more customization, you can select the cards you want from the Overworld and Underworld and combine them into your own unique deck of many things.

entries.name: Corrupted
entries: {@i Entitlement, Indulgence, Self-Obsession}

The liquid contained here is held greedily by the fae. A sense of entitlement, parsimony, and indulgence prevails. The blood is their own, symbolising complete self-sufficiency. This card represents energies flowing inward, self-sustainment, isolation from the outside world, and a focus on feelings buried deep within.

entries.name: Classical:
entries: {@i Depth, Compassion, Connection}
The traditional Ace of Cups is usually depicted as an overflowing cup with five streams (the senses), and represents love, deep feelings, compassion, new connections, and energies flowing outward.

card.name: Balance
entries: Your mind suffers a wrenching alteration, causing your alignment to change. Lawful becomes chaotic, good becomes evil, and vice versa. If you are true neutral or unaligned, this card has no effect on you. Found only in decks of twenty-two or forty-four cards.

card.name: Comet
entries: If you single-handedly defeat the next hostile monster or group of monsters you encounter, you gain experience points enough to gain one level. Otherwise, this card has no effect. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Death
entries: This is the representation of an {@creature avatar of death|FablemakerDeck}, a creature summoned by the Skull card. If you are using this deck as a deck of many things, remove the Death card first. (See page 12 for the {@creature avatar of death|FablemakerDeck} stat block.)

card.name: Donjon
entries: You disappear and become entombed in a state of suspended animation in an extradimensional sphere. Everything you were wearing and carrying stays behind in the space you occupied when you disappeared. You remain imprisoned until you are found and removed from the sphere. You can't be located by any divination magic, but a {@spell wish} spell can reveal the location of your prison. You draw no more cards. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Euryale
entries: The card's medusa-like visage curses you. You take a -2 penalty on saving throws while cursed in this way. Only a god or the magic of The Fates card can end this curse.

card.name: Fates
entries: Reality's fabric unravels and spins anew, allowing you to avoid or erase one event as if it never happened. You can use the card's magic as soon as you draw the card or at any other time before you die. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Flames
entries: A powerful devil becomes your enemy. The devil seeks your ruin and plagues your life, savoring your suffering before attempting to slay you. This enmity lasts until either you or the devil dies.

card.name: Fool
entries: You lose 10,000 XP, discard this card, and draw from the deck again, counting both draws as one of your declared draws. If losing that much XP would cause you to lose a level, you instead lose an amount that leaves you with just enough XP to keep your level. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Gem
entries: Twenty-five pieces of jewelry worth 2,000 gp each or fifty gems worth 1,000 gp each appear at your feet.

card.name: Idiot
entries: Permanently reduce your Intelligence score by 1d4 + 1 (to a minimum score of 1). You can draw one additional card beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Jester
entries: You gain 10,000 XP, or you can draw two additional cards beyond your declared draws.

card.name: Key
entries: A rare or rarer magic weapon with which you are proficient appears in your hands. The GM chooses the weapon.

card.name: Knight
entries: You gain the service of a 4th-level fighter who appears in a space you choose within 30 feet of you. The fighter is of the same race as you and serves you loyally until death, believing the fates have drawn him or her to you. You control this character.

card.name: Moon
entries: You are granted the ability to cast the {@spell wish} spell {@dice 1d3} times.

card.name: Rogue
entries: A nonplayer character of the GM's choice becomes hostile toward you. The identity of your new enemy isn't known until the NPC or someone else reveals it. Nothing less than a {@spell wish} spell or divine intervention can end the NPC's hostility toward you.

card.name: Ruin
entries: All forms of wealth that you carry or own, other than magic items, are lost to you. Portable property vanishes. Businesses, buildings, and land you own are lost in a way that alters reality the least. Any documentation that proves you should own something lost to this card also disappears.

card.name: Skull
entries: You summon an {@creature avatar of death|FablemakerDeck}—a ghostly humanoid skeleton clad in a tattered black robe and carrying a spectral scythe. It appears in a space of the GM's choice within 10 feet of you and attacks you, warning all others that you must win the battle alone. The avatar fights until you die or it drops to 0 hit points, whereupon it disappears. If anyone tries to help you, the helper summons its own avatar of death. A creature slain by an avatar of death can't be restored to life.

card.name: Star
entries: Increase one of your Ability Scores by 2. The score can exceed 20 but can't exceed 24.

card.name: Sun
entries: You gain 50,000 XP, and a wondrous item (which the GM determines randomly) appears in your hands.

card.name: Talons
entries: Every magic item you wear or carry disinte-grates. Artifacts in your possession aren't destroyed but do vanish. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Throne
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Persuasion} skill, and you double your proficiency bonus on checks made with that skill. In addition, you gain rightful ownership of a small keep somewhere in the world. However, the keep is currently in the hands of monsters, which you must clear out before you can claim the keep as yours.

card.name: Vizier
entries: At any time you choose within one year of the drawing this card, you can ask a question in meditation and mentally receive a truthful answer to that question. Besides information, the answer helps you solve a puzzling problem or other dilemma. In other words, the knowledge comes with wisdom on how to apply it. Found only in decks of twenty-two cards or forty-four cards.

card.name: Void
entries: This card spells disaster. Your soul is drawn from your body and contained in an object in a place of the GM's choice. One or more powerful beings guard the place. While your soul is trapped in this way, your body is {@condition incapacitated}. A wish spell can't restore your soul, but the spell reveals the location of the object that holds it. You draw no more cards.

book.name: The Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things Guidebook

How to Use the Deck for Oracle Readings

data.name: Welcome to the Fablemaker's Deck of Many Things
How to Use the Deck for Oracle Readings
entries: To consult the deck as an oracle, choose a problem, situation, or question in your life that you want to consider more deeply.
Shuffle both the Overworld and Underworld cards together and draw a card. Examine the imagery. How does it make you feel? Are there any symbols that resonate with you or your question?

You can look up the suggested themes, keywords, and interpre- tations in this book for each card or follow your own intuition for what the card means to you. Consider how what the card shows you might apply to the situation for which you are seeking clarity.
Beyond this simple way of using the cards to help you connect with your intuition, there are three other ways to use the colorful Overworld and monochrome Underworld to seek deeper meanings.

entries.name: Seeds of Change
entries: Seeds of Change are questions that explore the themes of the cards in more detail. The Overworld cards come with Seeds to address immediate and pressing issues, and the Underworld Seeds of Change pose questions to help you look beneath the surface with a new perspective.

When you draw a card, you can choose the Seeds of Change ques- tion that most resonates with you in the context of the problem you are trying to solve. You can also go through them one by one and consider them in turn, or you can roll a die to determine which one most needs your attention at random.

Remember to draw inspiration from the art on the card when you are reflecting on the Seeds. The art is as important as the guiding questions in the booklet. If you want to explore your situation further, draw another card and work through the Seeds in whichever way resonates most with you.

entries.name: {@font BALANCE|Firdevs}
entries: Balance is the great moderator of disagreements and encourages all parties to consider different perspectives. The central figure stands veiled, holding a sword and a set of scales. A white veil covers their face, symbolizing their commitment to look beyond what is familiar and consider new ideas without prejudice. The scales sit empty, awaiting input from different sides of the story. The figure's sword is drawn but remains at rest, which represents their readiness to act as well as their mercy and fairness. This card invites you to take a step back and think about viewpoints that you may not have considered before. The figure's raised wings and ready sword remind you that once a decision has been reached, action is the next step.

items: Have you weighed all sides of the issue and considered multiple viewpoints?
How would you feel if you were on the opposite side of the matter?
What emotions are influencing your perspective right now?
Are you seeing things as they are, or are you seeing things as you are?
Where can you find concrete knowledge to help you make a decision?
Are you taking the time and space to listen, or are you more focused on presenting your own opinions?
Is there something you must ignore so you can see more clearly without bias?
What are you currently balancing in your life, and are you treating these things fairly?
How have you formed your opinion on this matter?
Who in your life could you approach for their unique perspective?

entries.name: {@font COMET|Firdevs}
entries: The hero hurtles down, wreathed in flame. Wearing their gold helmet and holding their sword aloft, they descend and deliver a swift kick to their foe. They close their eyes, making the action look effortless, as their dramatic blaze of glory draws the viewer's gaze away from the hordes of monsters surrounding them . The hero wants their victory to shine in this moment, eclipsing any signs of struggle and concealing any weaknesses. They look valiant and radi- ant, but it's uncertain whether they'll be able to vanquish the other monsters on their own.

items: How does the reward for facing challenges alone differ from the reward for facing them with someone else?
What do you risk by asking for help?
Which is more enticing: solving the problem or looking good while solving it?
What advice would you give to someone you care about who was dealing with the same challenge?
How can you learn from the experience of solving this problem by yourself?
The seed of bravery is fear—what are you afraid of, and how can you face it?
What could you gain from asking for help?
Is it important to you that others see you solving the problem alone?
By focusing on this problem, what other problems are you ignoring?
When you succeed, how will you choose your next challenge?

entries.name: {@font DEATH|Firdevs}
entries: Death represents the struggle of self against self. Something within you may be holding you back. Endings are part of change for better and worse, and this card invites you to confront the aspects of your- self that you want to change honestly and compassionately. The figure depicted on this card is a part of you. Though it may look like one of your demons, it may, in fact, be a warning or a protector in disguise. It challenges you to seek resolution with a part of yourself that blocks a potential pathway to change and encourages you to consider whether or not this change will lead to positivity and growth. To prevail in this clash, all must be laid bare and self-deception cast aside. What you uncover beneath the figure's grisly mask may help you decide how to move forward.

items: What changes do you want for yourself?
What is still uncertain about the situation, and how do you feel about that uncertainty?
What feelings are you trying to ignore?
Think about an aspect of your life in which you feel stuck. What feelings emerge when you consider why you feel this way?
What feelings would you rather turn away from than confront?
What are the obstacles to the change you want?
Is your uncertainty coming from a fear of change itself?
How can you be more honest with yourself?
What do you need to move forward?
What is one way that you could honor your feelings about a difficult situation?
